attributes.title: Racial convergence and attitude toward interracial couples
attributes.description: This study investigates whether future Americans’ racial phenotype shapes White Americans’ opinion about the rising of multi-racial people and attitude toward inter-racial couples. In particular, it hypothesize that the less that typical future Americans will look like Whites, the more negative participants will feel about the rising of multi-racial people (H1) and (Black-White) inter-racial couples (H2).

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

other.value:
Participants’ ratings for the two feeling thermometers may be analyzed separately in case of a low reliability of the scale for attitude toward inter-racial couples.

Participants will also be asked a question how a "typical American" will look like. The choice ranges from an image for someone phenotypically Black (=1) to an image for someone phenotypically White (=7) with various choices for images that morphed the two in between. This item will be used as a manipulation check.

Participants will also use the feeling thermometers to rate their feelings toward White couples and Black couples. These items will be used for exploratory purposes.

sample.value: The survey will have 600 psychology students from a large mid-west university as participants.

analyses.value: Two t-tests will be used. One will compare participants’ attitude toward the rising of multi-racial people, and the other will compare their attitude toward inter-racial couples.

outliers.value: Only data from participants who identify as White will be included in the analysis.

dependent.value:
Dv1: Assume that the growth of multi-racial Americans eventually will make the differences between different racial groups fade away, creating just one racial group that is the mix of all racial groups we know today. Do you think it is a good thing or bad thing? (1=very bad, 9=very good)

Dv2 (an average of the following two items):
Using the "feeling thermometer" that you used earlier, how do you feel about couples where the female is Black and the male is White? There is no right or wrong answer.
(the question contains an image that illustrates a couple where the female is Black and the male is White)

Using the "feeling thermometer" that you used earlier, how do you feel about couples where the female is White and the male is Black? There is no right or wrong answer.

(the question contains an image that illustrates a couple where the female is White and the male is Black)

Both feeling thermometers range from 0=coldest to 100=warmest

conditions.value: For this study, there are 2 conditions. All participants will read an article about the demographic change regarding the growth of multiracial population. The article is also accompanied with a simulated image for what the most typical American might look like in the future. The racial phenotype of the individual in the image is manipulated across the conditions such that the individual in the image is either phenotypically more Black or White.

hypothesis.value: Future Americans’ racial phenotype shapes White Americans’ opinion about the rising of multi-racial people and attitude toward inter-racial couples. In particular, the less that typical future Americans will look like Whites, the more negative participants will feel about the rising of multi-racial people (H1) and (Black-White) inter-racial couples (H2).

registration_responses.data: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

Participants will also use the feeling thermometers to rate their feelings toward White couples and Black couples. These items will be used for exploratory purposes.

(the question contains an image that illustrates a couple where the female is Black and the male is White)

Using the "feeling thermometer" that you used earlier, how do you feel about couples where the female is White and the male is Black? There is no right or wrong answer.

attributes.title: COVID-19 and Stress
attributes.description: Anonymous survey measuring socio-demographic information, job/study status, mental health, protective factors and aggravating factors in the context of the COVID-19 pandemic

copyright_holders: Center for Studies on Human Stress

summary.value:
The current COVID-19 pandemic is a common source of stress and governmental measures are disrupting daily life in almost every country. This situation is a clear “experiment of nature” that could allow stress researchers to understand the psychological aspects of experiencing a pandemic in the 21st century.
Contrary to other crises, social isolation and radical changes in the way individuals go about their daily lives are at the center of the current pandemic. Studying the psychosocial aspects of this crisis can help the population make sense of the challenges they are going through and to be better prepared, should a   similar crisis occur in the future. Given the potential length of this crisis, it’s probable recurrence in the months/years to come and lasting repercussions it may have on society, stress scientists can help anticipate negative repercussions and foster positive adaptations in the population.
It is in that context that the Center for Studies on Human Stress (CSHS) has decided to launch an anonymous survey on psychological and social aspects of the COVID-19 crisis. This project is connected to a previous project, seeing as the ethics board of our research center could only process amendments to existing projects rather than full novel projects. This initial project was titled Brain Health for Economic Health (2019-1745) and was initially approved by the Institut Universitaire en Santé Mentale de Montréal’s research ethics committee on April 25th, 2019.
The anonymous survey includes a limited selection of questionnaires that were used in the 2019-1745 study, along with a few other questionnaires, for an estimated completion time of 30 minutes. The questionnaires will be described in the Material section and the full content of the survey can be found in the OSF project of this pre-registration.
Responses to the questionnaire will be matched with information that is relevant to the pandemic on the day that the response was completed. This will be done to account for variability that may be due to objective changes in the severity of the crisis. Furthermore, no biological samples will be collected during this study.

attributes.title: Optimism 7575-558-86
attributes.description: We hypothesie that people who are led to be optimistic about the future of the Covid-19 epidemic would find unethical behaviors less justifiable than people who are led to be pessimistic about the future of this epidemic.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

sample.value: In a previous study using an identical design, we found an effect size in the predicted direction with Cohen’s d = .40. Thus, we decided on a sample size of 200, which would give us 88% power to detect an effect size of Cohen’s d = .40, alpha = .05 (one-tailed). We will post a survey seeking 200 participants on Amazon Mechanical Turk. The final sample size might be higher or lower than 200 depending on the number of participants from unique IP addresses who complete our survey before it expires.

analyses.value: We will average participants’ responses to the five items measuring justifiability of unethical behavior, and run an independent samples t-test to assess whether participants are less likely to judge unethical behaviors as justifiable (i.e., are more likely to disagree with the items) in the optimism condition than in the pessimism condition. As we are pre-registering a directional hypothesis, we will use a one-tailed t-test.

outliers.value: Only participants who complete the study will be retained in the analysis. We will exclude multiple responses from the same IP address, based on the IP address recorded in the Qualtrics survey. We will also exclude participants who provide gibberish responses to an open-ended question asking them to summarize the main point of the information provided in the experimental manipulation (which was administered after the experimental manipulation but before the dependent variable).

dependent.value:
We will administer 5 items to measure the extent to which people find unethical behaviors justifiable:

1.	One friend says that it is OK to just go to work directly after returning from another country with infections without telling anyone, as long as you don’t show any respiratory symptoms.
2.	Another friend says that it is OK for companies to not give employees sick leave given the financial losses that companies are facing. 
3.	This friend also says that it is justifiable to take masks and hand sanitizer from office to home given how hard it is to buy them anywhere. 
4.	A third friend suggests that to avoid unnecessary panic, it is OK for the government to cover up bad news about the coronavirus. 
5.	Another friend suggests that if people are afraid of testing positive for the coronavirus, it is OK for them to just stay home and not go to the hospital to get tested. 

Participants would be asked to respond on a 11-point scale ranging from -5 = strongly disagree to 5 = strongly agree.

The average of these five items would serve as the dependent variable.

conditions.value: Participants will be randomly assigned to either the optimism condition or the pessimism condition. They will be presented with a scenario stating that the future of Covid-19 is bright vs. bleak, respectively, in the optimism condition vs. the pessimism condition. See attached pdf for detais.

hypothesis.value: We hypothesie that people who are led to be optimistic about the future of the Covid-19 epidemic would find unethical behaviors less justifiable than people who are led to be pessimistic about the future of this epidemic.

registration_responses.data: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

attributes.title: Social ties, norms and threat perception in the face of COVID-19
attributes.description:
Minimising physical contact with others is one of the most effective measures to alleviate the spread of COVID-19, and to enable the health systems to cope with the disease (WHO, 2020). This measure, also called “social distancing”, represents a paradigmatic, yet unprecedented form of collective action. It is paradigmatic because it relies on individuals’ readiness to change behaviour, invest effort and agree to self-sacrifices for a collective benefit (Zomeren & Iyer, 2009). It is unprecedented  because it needs to happen fast under threat conditions and it aims at a collective benefit which spans multiple geographical scales, from one’s own household to the entire planet.

In such threatening contexts, people typically seek further affiliation and social contact (Dezecache, 2015; Dezecache et al., 2017). Yet, what is currently required is to decrease the amount of physical social interactions, which poses a unique challenge for collective action. Sustaining such collective action can be materially and mentally costly to the individual by virtue of affecting daily life, causing cognitive dissonance, triggering moral re-evaluations and deviating from familiar behavioural norms (Strong, 1990). Having a supportive social network can help with sustaining collective action by improving psychological well-being (Helliwell & Putnam, 2004), providing a support network (Oliver & Marwell, 1988) and fostering a sense of normativity (Ostrom, 2000). Relatedly, research suggests that sustainable behaviour change depends not only on what one personally believes is right (unconditional norm-following) but also on what one thinks others in their social networks believe is right (conditional on normative social expectations) and de facto do (empirical social expectations; Bicchieri, 2016). Building on a “conditional norm-following” framework has proven to be effective in other contexts, for instance when initiating collective actions in India related to hygienic norms (World Bank Group, 2008). Can perceived threat, social ties and normative social expectations explain commitment to the collective action required to combat COVID-19 as well?

q1.value: Bahar Tuncgenc, Marwa El Zein, Yi Zhao, Justin Sulik, Guillaume Dezecache, Ophelia Deroy

q2.value:
AIM 1: To examine how the strength of people’s social ties predict their engagement in collective action (i.e., keeping physical distance from others) across cultures and over time.
Hypothesis 1a: Having stronger social ties will positively predict participants’ engagement in collective action (CA) through improving well-being.
Hypothesis 1b: The pattern hypothesised in 1a will be observed more strongly at the earlier stages of the pandemic as compared to later stages.
Hypothesis 1c: The pattern hypothesised in 1a will be observed more strongly in participants with a stronger collectivistic attitude.

AIM 2: To examine how perceived empirical vs normative beliefs of different social groups predict people’s engagement in collective action (i.e., keeping physical distance from others).
	Hypothesis 2a: Including participants’ expectations about others’ actions and beliefs will predict engagement in CA above and beyond their own personal beliefs about what should be done.
	Hypothesis 2b: At the earlier stages of the pandemic, higher expectations about others’ CA engagement  will predict the participants’ engagement in CA more than their expectations about others’ beliefs about what should be done. This pattern will dissolve and/or be reversed in later stages of the pandemic.
	Hypothesis 2c: The patterns hypothesised in 2a and 2b will be observed more strongly when “other” is defined as the close social network as compared to when the “other” is defined as the fellow citizens or the humankind.

AIM 3: To examine how perceived proximity of the threat of being infected and seeing others being infected, and personal vulnerability to the disease predict people’s commitment to collective action (i.e., keeping physical distance from others).
	Hypothesis 3a: Greater perceived vulnerability and threat will predict engagement in CA. 
	Hypothesis 3b: Perceived vulnerability of psychologically close ones will predict engagement in CA better than perceived vulnerability of self.
	Hypothesis 3c:Hypotheses 3a and 3b will be a function of the strength of social ties, collectivistic attitudes, and sense of fusion with other members of one’s own country.

AIM 4: To examine how attitudes towards science predicts people’s engagement in collective action. 
	Hypothesis 4: Lower ratings of belief in the credibility of science will predict lower engagement in CA.

q3.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
Participants will be asked to complete an online survey presented to them on the Qualtrics XM survey platform at six time points that are two weeks apart from each other.

The survey will comprise of (a) demographics questions, (b) proximity of threat related to the coronavirus outbreak, (c) the Social Network Questionnaire (Stiller & Dunbar, 2007), (d) Empirical vs normative expectations questionnaire (Bicchieri & Xiao, 2009), (e) attitudes towards the coronavirus outbreak, (f) the Warwick-Edinburgh Mental Well-being Scale (Tennant et al., 2007), and (g) belief in the credibility of science.

In addition, only at T1, baseline measures will be obtained for (a) closeness to one’s own country and government (Inclusion of Other in Self scale: Aron, Aron & Smollan, 1992), (b) single-item political identification scale, (c) emotional quotient (Wakabayashi et al., 2006), and (d) vertical collectivism scale (Singelis, Triandis, Bhawuk & Gelfand, 1995).
This is an observational study examining how natural variability in people’s commitment to the collective action of keeping physical distance from others can be predicted from (a) the size of their closely-bonded social network, (b) their personal beliefs about what should be done vs. their expectations about others’ beliefs about what should be done, (c) their expectations about others’ commitment to the collective action vs. their expectations about others’ beliefs about what should be done, and (d) the social closeness of the “other” category in (b) and (c), i.e., with levels being close social network, fellow citizens and humankind.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
We aim to collect longitudinal data from 13 target countries (i.e., Australia, Bangladesh, China, France, Germany, Italy, Iran, Lebanon, Spain, Sweden, Turkey, UK, USA) to have a representative, non-WEIRD sample (Henrich, Heine & Norenzayan, 2010) at six time-points that are two weeks apart from each other. The list of countries and time-points may be revised depending on ease of recruitment.

As is common in cross-cultural research, participation will be on a voluntary basis to obtain an as unbiased sample as possible across cultures and different social-economic groups in the population. For participant recruitment, snowball sampling (through existing contacts) and volunteer sampling (through calls for participation in wider networks) methods will be employed. Invitations will be sent out to existing social networks of the study team in various countries. In addition, advertisements will be made in target community groups, social media platforms, and relevant charities and organisations (e.g., Age UK, Johns Hopkins University School of Public Health, Cancer Care & Research Trust Bangladesh etc.).

q11.value:
We do not have an a priori stopping rule for data collection given that the goal of this study is to reach an as representative sample as possible over time. Due to the longitudinal nature of this study spanning a period of 3 months, we anticipate a relatively high drop-out rate.

For the analysis of the longitudinal data, we will group participants into time points if they are maximum 7 days apart from each other in completing the survey. We will start analysing the T1 data when 50 complete data sets have been obtained from a given country.

question.value:
The English version of the survey used can be found attached to this pre-registration.

Collective action: Participants’ answers to the survey items “I have been following this general advice where I live” and “In the past 7 days, how much have you been going out?” will be used as an index of how much they have engaged in CA. Zero and positive scores will indicate high engagement, and negative scores will indicate low engagement.
Social ties: The size of the participants’ social clique will be used as an index of the strength of their social ties. The size of the social clique will be determined through the Social Network Questionnaire (Stiller & Dunbar, 2007) as the number of people with whom the participant has had a conversation in the past week and those whom the participant would turn to for help with a major problem.

Stages of the pandemic: We will use the number of cases (as reported in:  https://coronavirus.jhu.edu/map.html) and index of measures taken in the country (as reported in: https://www.bsg.ox.ac.uk/research/research-projects/oxford-covid-19-government-response-tracker) as indicative of what stage the pandemic is in any given country. The stages will be mapped onto the three-stage model of pandemic management: prevention, resilience and recovery.

Personal normative belief: Participants’ answer to the survey item “I think that it is wrong not to follow this general advice” will be used as an index of how much they believe that the CA should be done, with higher scores indicating stronger belief in the CA.
Empirical expectations about others’ action: Participants’ answer to the survey items “[Others ]have been following this general advice where they live” will be used as an index of how much they expect others to believe that the CA should be done, with higher scores indicating stronger expectations. This item will be repeated three times with the word “Other” replaced with “people in my close network”, “people in my country”, and “people all around the world”. 

Normative expectations about others’ belief: Participants’ answer to the survey items “[Others] think that it is wrong not to follow this general advice” will be used as an index of how much they expect others to believe that the CA should be done, with higher scores indicating stronger expectations. This item will be repeated three times with the word “Other” replaced with “people in my close network”, “people in my country”, and “people all around the world”.

Proximity of threat: The following two questions will be used to calculate participants’ sense of vulnerability and threat to the self,  to household members, and other loved ones, with higher scores indicating a stronger perception of threat: “How would you rate the vulnerability of the following people to the coronavirus disease: myself, someone I care about in my household, someone I care about outside of my household?” and “How much do you think the following people had the coronavirus disease: myself, someone I care about in my household, someone I care about outside of my household?”. Answers to the question of “myself” will indicate perceived personal vulnerability, “someone I care about in my household” will indicate perceived vulnerability of physically and psychologically close ones, and “someone I care about outside of my household” will indicate perceived vulnerability of only psychologically, but not physically, close ones.

Belief in the credibility of science: Participants’ answers to the following survey items will indicate their belief in the credibility of science, with lower scores indicating a stronger belief in science: “People trust scientists a lot more than they should.”, “A lot of scientific theories are dead wrong.” and “Our society places too much emphasis on science.”

Longitudinal data analysis approaches will be firstly applied to summarize the CA trajectories. We will use general mixed models to identify which of our predictors influence CA, and mediation analysis (e.g., to test Hypothesis 1a) using R statistical computing software’s lme4 and mediate packages (or other packages with similar functionality). The inverse probability weighting approach will be considered to remove the sampling bias. Network-based methods will be employed when analysing social network related questions. Moderation analysis will be conducted articulating potential confounding effects.

q19.value: Standard p < .05 criteria will be used as statistical inference cut-off.

q22.value:
In addition to our main constructs of interest, we will explore the links between belief in collective vs individual responsibility, belief in group vs individual efficacy, well-being, empathy, medium used in recent social interactions, mood, well-being, science orientation and demographic factors.

We will explore how the main hypotheses and the above-mentioned factors change over time and across cultures. The cross-cultural comparisons will take into account factors such as the severity of the disease in that country (as reported in: https://coronavirus.jhu.edu/map.html), the mean collectivist attitude of the participants in that country, and the degree of measures taken by the authorities in that country (as reported in: https://www.bsg.ox.ac.uk/research/research-projects/oxford-covid-19-government-response-tracker).

The survey will comprise of (a) demographics questions, (b) proximity of threat related to the coronavirus outbreak, (c) the Social Network Questionnaire (Stiller & Dunbar, 2007), (d) Empirical vs normative expectations questionnaire (Bicchieri & Xiao, 2009), (e) attitudes towards the coronavirus outbreak, (f) the Warwick-Edinburgh Mental Well-being Scale (Tennant et al., 2007), and (g) belief in the credibility of science.

In addition, only at T1, baseline measures will be obtained for (a) closeness to one’s own country and government (Inclusion of Other in Self scale: Aron, Aron & Smollan, 1992), (b) single-item political identification scale, (c) emotional quotient (Wakabayashi et al., 2006), and (d) vertical collectivism scale (Singelis, Triandis, Bhawuk & Gelfand, 1995).
This is an observational study examining how natural variability in people’s commitment to the collective action of keeping physical distance from others can be predicted from (a) the size of their closely-bonded social network, (b) their personal beliefs about what should be done vs. their expectations about others’ beliefs about what should be done, (c) their expectations about others’ commitment to the collective action vs. their expectations about others’ beliefs about what should be done, and (d) the social closeness of the “other” category in (b) and (c), i.e., with levels being close social network, fellow citizens and humankind.
registration_responses.q10.question:
We aim to collect longitudinal data from 13 target countries (i.e., Australia, Bangladesh, China, France, Germany, Italy, Iran, Lebanon, Spain, Sweden, Turkey, UK, USA) to have a representative, non-WEIRD sample (Henrich, Heine & Norenzayan, 2010) at six time-points that are two weeks apart from each other. The list of countries and time-points may be revised depending on ease of recruitment.

As is common in cross-cultural research, participation will be on a voluntary basis to obtain an as unbiased sample as possible across cultures and different social-economic groups in the population. For participant recruitment, snowball sampling (through existing contacts) and volunteer sampling (through calls for participation in wider networks) methods will be employed. Invitations will be sent out to existing social networks of the study team in various countries. In addition, advertisements will be made in target community groups, social media platforms, and relevant charities and organisations (e.g., Age UK, Johns Hopkins University School of Public Health, Cancer Care & Research Trust Bangladesh etc.).
registration_responses.q15.question:
The English version of the survey used can be found attached to this pre-registration.

Collective action: Participants’ answers to the survey items “I have been following this general advice where I live” and “In the past 7 days, how much have you been going out?” will be used as an index of how much they have engaged in CA. Zero and positive scores will indicate high engagement, and negative scores will indicate low engagement.
Social ties: The size of the participants’ social clique will be used as an index of the strength of their social ties. The size of the social clique will be determined through the Social Network Questionnaire (Stiller & Dunbar, 2007) as the number of people with whom the participant has had a conversation in the past week and those whom the participant would turn to for help with a major problem.

Stages of the pandemic: We will use the number of cases (as reported in:  https://coronavirus.jhu.edu/map.html) and index of measures taken in the country (as reported in: https://www.bsg.ox.ac.uk/research/research-projects/oxford-covid-19-government-response-tracker) as indicative of what stage the pandemic is in any given country. The stages will be mapped onto the three-stage model of pandemic management: prevention, resilience and recovery.

Personal normative belief: Participants’ answer to the survey item “I think that it is wrong not to follow this general advice” will be used as an index of how much they believe that the CA should be done, with higher scores indicating stronger belief in the CA.
Empirical expectations about others’ action: Participants’ answer to the survey items “[Others ]have been following this general advice where they live” will be used as an index of how much they expect others to believe that the CA should be done, with higher scores indicating stronger expectations. This item will be repeated three times with the word “Other” replaced with “people in my close network”, “people in my country”, and “people all around the world”. 

Normative expectations about others’ belief: Participants’ answer to the survey items “[Others] think that it is wrong not to follow this general advice” will be used as an index of how much they expect others to believe that the CA should be done, with higher scores indicating stronger expectations. This item will be repeated three times with the word “Other” replaced with “people in my close network”, “people in my country”, and “people all around the world”.

Proximity of threat: The following two questions will be used to calculate participants’ sense of vulnerability and threat to the self,  to household members, and other loved ones, with higher scores indicating a stronger perception of threat: “How would you rate the vulnerability of the following people to the coronavirus disease: myself, someone I care about in my household, someone I care about outside of my household?” and “How much do you think the following people had the coronavirus disease: myself, someone I care about in my household, someone I care about outside of my household?”. Answers to the question of “myself” will indicate perceived personal vulnerability, “someone I care about in my household” will indicate perceived vulnerability of physically and psychologically close ones, and “someone I care about outside of my household” will indicate perceived vulnerability of only psychologically, but not physically, close ones.

Belief in the credibility of science: Participants’ answers to the following survey items will indicate their belief in the credibility of science, with lower scores indicating a stronger belief in science: “People trust scientists a lot more than they should.”, “A lot of scientific theories are dead wrong.” and “Our society places too much emphasis on science.”
registration_responses.q17.question: Longitudinal data analysis approaches will be firstly applied to summarize the CA trajectories. We will use general mixed models to identify which of our predictors influence CA, and mediation analysis (e.g., to test Hypothesis 1a) using R statistical computing software’s lme4 and mediate packages (or other packages with similar functionality). The inverse probability weighting approach will be considered to remove the sampling bias. Network-based methods will be employed when analysing social network related questions. Moderation analysis will be conducted articulating potential confounding effects.

attributes.title: COVID-19, Stay-Home Orders and Well-Being: Evidence from Google Trends
attributes.description: This paper will investigate the impact of the government response to COVID-19 on health and well-being using Google Trends data. More precisely, we aim to test the impact of stay-home orders on 12 Google Trend topics related to health and well-being in the US and Europe.

attributes.title: The Short-Term Effect of COVID-19 on Employment and Wages
attributes.description: This paper examines the short-term consequences of COVID-19 on employment and wages in the U.S. Guided by a pre-analysis plan, we document the impact of COVID-19 at the national-level using a simple difference and test whether states with relatively more confirmed cases were more affected.

attributes.title: COVID-19 Response and Sub-types of Antisocial Behaviors
attributes.description: The purpose of this research is to help assess the ecological validity of the Sub-Types of Antisocial Behavior (STAB) questionnaire (Burt and Donnellan, 2009). Our laboratory has previously shown that the STAB (specifically, the social aggression sub-score) is associated with reduced empathic sensitivity in a laboratory-based task (O’Connell et al., under review), while other groups have linked heightened STAB scores to reduced ambiguity aversion (Buckholtz et al., 2017). We expect this measure will map onto real-world behavioral responses during the COVID-19 pandemic—that is, individuals reporting increased antisocial behaviors will report reduced engagement in social distancing.

attributes.title: Culture, Cognition, and Social Exchange:  A Classic Case Study of  Social Negotiation Network Dynamics
attributes.description: How  do automatic vs. controlled, hot vs. cold, and  agentic vs. communal facets of cultural cognition operate together in a perspective informed by social neuroscience?  This question is explored by re-imagining Malinowski’s classic ethnographic case study of the Kula in light of a contemporary social exchange theory of negotiation networks.  We propose: (1) sub-institutional patterns of power-dependence form a structural foundation for the rise of tacit meanings, which evolve through social negotiation into explicit, cultural meaning agreements; (2)  crucial sub-cultural categories form around the pursuit of both agentic  benefits and communal benefits; (3) an individual is culturally shaped through externalization, socialization, and internalization to value and seek both kinds of benefits; (4) an individual faces the existential task of navigating both agentic and communal situations across the negotiation network; (5)  the basic individual mechanism underlying such navigation entails motivated behavioral choice and motivated cultural cognition; (6) a behavioral choice rests on automatic, largely implicit and hot cognitive processing; (7) motivated cultural cognition rests mostly on the deliberate, mostly explicit, and cool selection of materials from the prevailing cultural toolkit for assembling a justification, but whose underlying trajectory is biased by an automatic, hot value-position, whether agentic or communal.  Based on the analysis, some directions for future empirical research are suggested.
tags: hot vs. cold  automatic vs. deliberative implicit vs. explicit agentic vs. communal power-dependence negotiation network inequality

attributes.title: Power Analyses
attributes.description: The purpose of this study is to explore people’s subjective well-being during the COVID-19 pandemic. We are interested in how the type of activities people engage in while practicing social distancing influences their well-being. This is an exploratory study.

q2.value: This is an exploratory study. Our research question is how people's well-being is influenced by the COVID-19 pandemic and the practice of social distancing. We predict that people's subjective well-being during the pandemic will be determined by their daily behavior, including social and nonsocial activities as well as digital and nondigital activities.

q3.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: This is a correlational study. We plan to send participants a follow-up survey after the COVID-19 pandemic is over and social distancing recommendations have been withdrawn. This will allow us to conduct pair-samples analyses.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited from the population of people residing in the United States through TurkPrime Panels.

q11.value: We determined that for detecting small effect sizes, r = .15 with 90% power, we need at least 459 participants. Thus, we set out to recruit 500 participants.

q12.value: We plan to send participants a follow-up survey after the pandemic is over and social distancing recommendations have been withdrawn. Assuming a return rate of 50% for the follow-up study (N = 250), sensitivity analyses indicated that we will achieve 90% power to detect small effects, Cohen’s d = .21.

question.value: The full survey is attached. The main outcome variables are positive and negative affect in the past week (SPANE scale), life satisfaction (Cantril ladder), stress (Perceived Stress Scale), social connectedness (social connectedness scale), and the trust. The main predictors are in-person and digital social interactions and digital device screentime.
Correlations, multiple regressions, and paired-samples t-tests will be used.

q21.value: Missing data will not be imputed.
